docs.abstract: Urban Market, new food shop on West 26th Street in Manhattan, noted; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: THE scent of cumin and garlic hangs in the air at the Urban Market, 117-119 West 26th Street, a homey yet highly professional new food shop that offers an unusual blend of cuisines for takeout and catering. The owner, Claudia Sidoti, is a caterer with a diverse family background: her father is Italian, her mother is Colombian and her mother-in-law is Antiguan. They all contribute to the cooking. In a neighborhood that is home to the flower market, sewing-machine repair shops and photography studios, such a mixture of cuisines feels right.

headline.main: Joyce Chen, 76, U.S. Popularizer Of Mandarin Cuisine

docs.lead_paragraph: Joyce Chen, who popularized Mandarin cuisine in America with her restaurants, cookbooks and television programs, died on Tuesday in the Fairlawn Nursing Home in Lexington. She was 76. She suffered from Alzheimer's disease.

headline.main: FRENCH CUISINE IS BECOMING A BIT LESS FRENCH

docs.lead_paragraph: French cooking, which has become renowned worldwide, may not be so French after all. A Government report has found that the country's cooking is prepared mostly by foreign chefs.
docs.snippet: French cooking, which has become renowned worldwide, may not be so French after all. A Government report has found that the country's cooking is prepared mostly by foreign chefs....

headline.main: TRAVEL ADVISORY: NEEDLEWORK OF CHINA, CUISINE OF SPAIN

docs.lead_paragraph: Chance to See Embroidery Of the East Participants in a tour along a route that twines from Peking to Xian to Shanghai, Hangzhou and other major cities of China, will see more than such attractions as the Forbidden City, the Children's Palace and the Grand Canal. The trip, scheduled for Sept. 18 to Oct. 6, also holds the promise of special viewings of needlework, including intricate double-sided embroidery. (Rather than have both sides identical, double-sided embroidery - worked with a silk thread on gauze - might, for example, have a peacock in gleaming white on one side and in greens and blues on the other.) Participants will also be affored ample opportunities to savor the country's arts and crafts. This tour, which is not confined to lovers of needlework, will be led by Erica Wilson, the needleworker and syndicated needlework columnist, joined by her husband, Vladimir Kagan, a leading designer of modern furniture.

headline.main: by Moira Hodgson; French nouvelle and classic cuisine.

docs.lead_paragraph: TWO very different French restaurants opened recently at opposite ends of town. One is classic French, the other nouvelle cuisine. They have in common a good kitchen, an efficient and professional staff and attractive surroundings. The warehouse district of Lower Manhattan is not the place one would expect to find French food, or indeed any first-class cooking, but the Odeon, a former cafeteria on West Broadway at Thomas Street, serves fine nouvelle cuisine. It is owned by a former waiter, Keith McNally, who is venturing into restaurant management for the first time. The warehouse-lined streets are no longer totally dark and empty at night. The gaunt buildings are rapidly being converted to lofts, restaurants and shops.

headline.main: Le Fooding – haute cuisine for the masses in Paris
